Chapter on the Lion's Roar Bodhisattva, Part 3
The Lion's Roar said:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said:
All dharmas have two kinds of causes:
First, the direct cause; second, the contributory cause.
Because of these two causes, there should be no bondage or liberation.
These five skandhas arise and cease moment by moment.
If they arise and cease like this, who is bound?
Who is liberated?
World-Honored One!

Based on these five skandhas, the subsequent five skandhas arise. These skandhas cease by themselves and do not reach those skandhas. Although they do not reach them, they can give rise to those skandhas.
It is like a seed giving rise to a sprout. The seed does not reach the sprout. Although it does not reach it, it can give rise to the sprout.
Sentient beings are also like this. How can there be bondage or liberation?
Good man!
Listen carefully, listen carefully! I will explain it to you in detail.
Good man!
It is like when a person is about to die and is experiencing great suffering, surrounded by their relatives who are crying and lamenting.

The person is terrified and has no one to rely on for rescue. Although they have the five sense faculties, they are unaware of anything. Their limbs tremble and shake, unable to support themselves. Their body is cold and the warmth is about to dissipate. They see the signs of the rewards and retributions for the good and evil they have cultivated.
Good man!
It is like when the sun is about to set, the shadows of hills and mounds move east, but it is not the case that they move west.

The fruits of karma for sentient beings are also like this. When this aggregate ceases, the next aggregate continues to arise. It is like when a lamp is lit, the darkness disappears, and when the lamp is extinguished, the darkness returns.
Good man!
It is like a wax seal stamping mud. The seal and the mud join, and when the seal is removed, the impression is formed. But the wax seal does not change and remain in the mud.
The impression is not produced from the mud, nor does it come from elsewhere. It arises due to the conditions of the seal.
The present aggregate ceases, and the intermediate state aggregate arises.
The present aggregates will never transform into the intermediate existence aggregates.
The intermediate existence aggregates are not born from themselves, nor do they come from elsewhere.
Because of the present aggregates, the intermediate existence aggregates arise.
It is like a seal stamping mud - the seal is destroyed and the pattern is formed. Although the names are not different, the time periods are each different.
Therefore, I say the intermediate existence aggregates are not seen by the physical eye, but are seen by the heavenly eye.
In the intermediate existence, there are three kinds of food:
First, thought food; second, contact food; third, intention food.
There are two kinds of intermediate existence:
First, the result of good karma; second, the result of bad karma.
Because of good karma, one obtains good contemplation;
Because of bad karma, one obtains bad contemplation.
When the parents unite, according to karmic conditions, one moves towards the place of rebirth. One feels love for the mother and hatred for the father.
When the father's semen is emitted, one thinks it already exists. Seeing it, one's mind is delighted and one feels joyful.
Due to these three kinds of afflictions, the intermediate existence and the five aggregates are born, like a seal stamping mud, the seal is destroyed and the pattern is formed.
At the time of birth, the faculties are either complete or incomplete.
Those with complete faculties see form and give rise to craving. Because of giving rise to craving, it is called love;
Because of delusion, craving arises, this is called ignorance.

Because of the two causes of craving and ignorance, all the perceived objects are completely inverted, seeing permanence in impermanence, seeing self in non-self, seeing bliss in suffering, and seeing purity in impurity.
Because of the four inversions, one creates good and evil actions. Afflictions create karma, and karma creates afflictions. This is called bondage.
For this reason, it is called the arising of the five aggregates.
If this person gets to be close to the Buddha, the Buddha's disciples, and good spiritual friends, he will then get to hear and accept the twelve divisions of the scriptures;
Because of hearing the Dharma, he contemplates the good objects;
Because of contemplating the good objects, he attains great wisdom;
One of great wisdom is called one of right knowledge and insight;
Because one has knowledge and insight, one gives rise to a sense of regret in the midst of birth and death;
Because one gives rise to a sense of regret, one does not give rise to joy and pleasure;
Because one does not give rise to joy and pleasure, one is able to destroy the mind of greed;
Because one destroys the mind of greed, one cultivates the Eightfold Noble Path;
Because one cultivates the Eightfold Noble Path, one attains freedom from birth and death;
Because one is free from birth and death, it is called attaining liberation.
Just as fire, when it does not encounter fuel, is called extinguished;
Because one extinguishes birth and death, it is called parinirvÄá¹‡a.
For this reason, it is called the cessation of the five aggregates.
Siá¹ƒha said:
There are no thorns in space, so how can one say they are pulled out?
Since there is no bondage in the aggregates, how can they be bound?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The fetters of afflictions bind the five aggregates. Apart from the five aggregates, there are no separate afflictions;
Apart from the afflictions, there are no separate five aggregates.
Good man!
Just as a pillar supports a house, apart from the house there is no pillar, apart from the pillar there is no house.
The five skandhas of sentient beings are also like this. Because there are afflictions, they are called bound;
Because there are no afflictions, they are called liberated.
Good man!
Just like a fist, a palm, and a bond - these three are combined, scattered, produced, and extinguished, and there is no separate dharma.
The five skandhas of sentient beings are also like this. Because there are afflictions, they are called bound;
Because there are no afflictions, they are called liberated.
Good man!
It is said that name-and-form binds sentient beings. If name-and-form ceases, then there are no sentient beings - apart from name-and-form, there are no separate sentient beings;
Apart from sentient beings, there is no separate name-and-form - it is also called name-and-form binding sentient beings, and it is also called sentient beings binding name-and-form.

World-Honored One!
Just as the eye cannot see itself, the finger cannot touch itself, the knife cannot cut itself, and feeling cannot feel itself, how can the TathÄgata say that name-and-form binds name-and-form?
Why is it so?
Name-and-form is precisely sentient beings, and sentient beings are precisely name-and-form.
If it is said that name-and-form binds sentient beings, then name-and-form binds name-and-form.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
When two hands come together, there is no other separate thing that comes to join them;
Name and form are also like this.
For this reason, I say that name-and-form binds sentient beings. If one is apart from name-and-form, one will attain liberation.
Therefore, I say that sentient beings are liberated.
Siá¹ƒha said:
World-Honored One!
If having name-and-form is bondage, then the arhats who have not yet transcended name-and-form should also be bound.
Good man!
There are two kinds of liberation:
First, the cutting of the seeds, and second, the cutting of the fruits.
As for the cutting of the seeds, it refers to the severing of afflictions.
Arhats and others have already severed afflictions, and the bonds are rotten, therefore the bonds of the seeds cannot bind them.
Because the fruits have not been severed, they are called bound by fruits.
Arhats do not see the Buddha-nature, and because they do not see it, they do not attain anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
For this reason, it can be said that they are bound by fruits, but it cannot be said that they are bound by name-and-form.
Good man!
It is like a burning lamp, the light will not go out as long as the oil has not been exhausted;
if the oil is exhausted, the going out is certain.
Good man!
As for the oil, it is a metaphor for the afflictions;

The afflictions of sentient beings are not like this. Sentient beings are precisely afflictions, and afflictions are precisely sentient beings.
The name sentient beings refers to the five aggregates, and the five aggregates are called sentient beings;

The Buddha said:

There are eight kinds of similes:
